results.title: Providence
results.creator_credit: Alain Resnais, Klaus Hellwig, Yves Gasser and Yves Peyrot
results.brief_description:
This is a perversely hilarious comedy about one restless night (among many) in the fading life of ageing, over-sexed novelist, Clive Langham. Clive lives alone in a country mansion and spends his nights cursing his fate as he inserts suppositories, sits on the ‘throne’ and downs bottle after bottle of white wine. In his nightmare, the characters of his novel mix with his real life relatives. As Clive gathers his relatives around him for a final week-end and they attempt to nurse him back to life, he realises that they are not the monsters he perceived them to be.

Credits: Produces, Yves Gasser, Yves Renot, Klaus Hellwig ; director, Alain Resnais ; writers, David Mercer ; photography, Ricardo Aronovitch ; music, Miklos Rozsa ; art direction, Jacques Saulnier.
Cast: Dirk Bogarde, Ellen Burstyn, John Gielgud, David Warner, Elain Stritch, Peter Arne.

results.title: L'annee Derniere a Marienbad = Last Year in Marienbad (Cinemascope Print)
results.creator_credit: Alain Resnais, Pierre Courau and Raymond Froment
results.brief_description:
Robbe-Grillet described ‘Marienbad’ as ‘the story of a persuading’ centred on a romantic triangle ending in violence, constructed in the mind of X, one of the three. To Resnais, ‘Marienbad’ looks like a statue and sounds like an opera’. The images of the chateau are those of a labyrinth of fake trails, variants, failures and repetitions, destroying spatial and temporal logic in a film about the processes of memory that locates everything in the present tense. In keeping with Robbe-Grillet’s rejection of conventional interior monologue the emphasis is not on what X is thinking and feeling but on what he ‘sees’. With a hint of playfulness Resnais’ treatment of Robbe-Grillet’s script suggests a meditation on narrative tyranny, a modernist demonstration of narrative cinema as process: instead of the image revealing the world, it reveals itself. Awards: Best Film Venice Film Festival (Mostra) 1961 ; Prix Georges Melies 1961 ; Prix Andre Bazin 1961.

Credits: Producers, Pierre Courau, Raymond Froment ; director, Alain Resnais ; writer, Alain Robbe-Grillet ; photography, Sacha Vierny ; music, Francis Seyrig ; art direction, Jacques Saulnier ; assistant director, Volker Schloendorff.
Cast: Giorgio Albertazzi, Delphine Seyrig, Sacha Pitoeff.

results.title: Clementine Tango
results.brief_description:
Charles, a law student, shares a sumptuous Paris apartment with his sister. One day, he finds a very strange love letter in the pocket of his father’s tuxedo. While trying to understand his father’s love entanglements, he is led to a Pigalle nightclub where act after act is performed with the intent of splintering bourgeois sexual mores into humorous pieces. The ‘cinema du look’ is not quite confined to the films of Beineix, Besson and Carax, the tree neo-baroque ‘wonder boys’. Caroline Roboh’s camp cabaret ‘Clementine Tango’ (1982) belongs to the genre too, as does Virginie Thevenet ‘La nuit porte-jaretelles’ (1985), which led ‘Les Cahiers du Cinema’ to coin the phrase ‘style Forum des Halles’, and prompted an attack from ‘Positif’ on the quality of the narrative, acting, and portrayal of sexuality.” Guy Austin. ‘Contemporary French cinema’. Manchester University Press, 1996.

Credits: Producer, Vladimir Forgency ; director, Caroline Roboh ; writer, Caroline Roboh ; photography, Mario Barroso.
Cast: Claire Pascal, Francois Helvey, Caroline Roboh, Arturo Brachetti, Josephine Larsen.

results.title: Ben et Benedict = Ben and Benedict
results.brief_description:
Ben is a woman who never gets to do what she really wants to and is the victim of everybody and everything. Benedict is her imaginary creation: the girl who would respond with strength and mastery to situations Ben can only submit to. She is married to a cad who says he only married her because she was pregnant, and now he wants his freedom. Her real love is a fellow medical student who shows some interest in her. Nonetheless, she remains faithful to her unenthusiastic husband, until she becomes pregnant again. At this point she begins to act more like the Benedict of her dreams and less like the Ben she has lived as until now.

Credits: Producer, Claude Nedjar ; director, Paula Delsol ; writer, Paula Delsol ; photography, Claude Beausoleil ; music, Larry Martin ; title song, Pierre Barouh.
Cast: Francoise Lebrun, Andre Dussolier, Daniel Duval, Francois Perrier [voice only], Jacques Jeannet.

results.title: L'une et L'autre = the Other One
results.brief_description:
A young actress, with a rather fragile personality, borrows her sister’s identity in order to break-up with her current lover.

Credits: Producer, Nicole Stephane ; director, Rene Allio ; writers, Rene Allio, Gerard Pollicand ; photography, Jean Badal ; music, Serge Gainsbourg.
Cast: Philippe Noiret, Claude Dauphin, Malka Ribowska, Francoise Prevost, Christian Alers.

results.title: Liberte 1 = Liberty 1 (Cinemascope Print)
results.brief_description:
Michel is in charge of building a road cutting through the savanna of Senegal. When the building work threatens a sacred tree, Michel has to face the wrath of the villagers of Tiolene. The film looks at the difficulties faced by an ex-colony once it has received its independence. Corrupt structures do not disappear with the colonialists, but remained ingrained in the practices of the indigenous bourgeois class. This film was the first French-Senegal co-production. See also: ‘Xala’ (Ousmane Sembene, 1974) held in our collection.

Credits: Producer, Jean Cotet ; director, Yves Ciampi ; witers,
Cast: Corinne Marchand, Maurice Ronet, Nanette Senghor, Iba Guey

results.title: Remontons les Champs-Elysees = Let's Walk Back Up to the Champs-Elysees
results.creator_credit: Robert Bibal, Guy Lacourt and Serge Sandberg
results.brief_description:
In order to break the routine of his lessons, a school teacher decides to tell his pupils the story of the Champs-Elysees, from the Renaissance to Napoleon III. This light historical comedy is a pretext for Guitry to play five roles and to play games with historical facts and famous characters.

Credits: Producers, Guy Lacourt, Serge Sandberg ; directors, Robert Bibal, Sacha Guitry ; writer, Sacha Guitry ; photography, Jean Bachelet ; music, Adolphe Borchard ; stills photographer, Raymond Voinquel.
Cast: Sacha Guitry, Jean Davy, Jacqueline Delubac, Jane Marken, Mila Parely, Jeanne Boitel, Lucien Baroux.

results.title: Une Aussi Longue Absence = the Long Absence
results.creator_credit: Henri Colpi, Claude Jaeger and Jacques Nahum
results.brief_description:
In this touching tearjerker, a lonesome owner of a Parisian cafÃ© spies on a passing tramp. He hums a strangely familiar tune and the woman is convinced that he is her estranged husband who was deported 16 years before. She follows the wanderer back to his miserable shanty beside the Seine, where she learns that he has been an amnesiac since the war. She takes him back to her cafe in the hope that it will jog his failed memory and sees a terrible scar on the back of his head. In her heart, she realises his memory will never return, but this does not stop her from spending the rest of her days trying to get him to remember something from their happy past. With ‘Une aussi longue absence’ Colpi has used his cinematic knowledge to serve a sensitivity, a quality of emotion, a delightful purity and a humanity very rarely seen on the screen nowadays. With images of a great beauty (by Marcel Weiss), the film delivers a remarkable sketch of a suburban community”. Reference: Le Film Francais, 16 June 1961. Awards: Prix Louis-Delluc 1960 ; Palme d’Or Cannes Film Festival 1961.

Credits: Producers, Jacques Nahum, Claude Jaeger; director, Henri Colpi ; writers, Marguerite Duras, Gerard Jarlot, Henri Colpi ; photography, Marcel Weiss ; music, Georges Delerue.
Cast: Alida Valli, Georges Wilson, Amedee, Charles Blavette, Nane Germon.

results.title: Poulet Au Vinaigre = Cop Au Vin
results.brief_description:
A quiet little town, like so many others … Doctor Philippe Morasseau, attorney Hubert Lavoisier and butcher Gerard Filiol are partners in a building project. But first, they must evict the widow Cuno and her son, the village postman. Things take a nasty turn when the doctor’s wife disappears and the butcher dies in a car accident. Enters Inspector Lavardin, a hard-nosed cop with unconventional methods. The film was a great box-office success and was followed by a sequel, ‘Inspecteur Lavardin’ in 1985.

Credits: Producer, Marin Karmitz ; director, Claude Chabrol ; writers, Claude Chabrol, Dominique Roulet ; photography, Jean Rabier ; music, Matthieu Chabrol.
Cast: Jean Poiret, Michel Bouquet, Lucas Belvaux, Jean-Claude Bouillaud, Caroline Cellier, Josephine Chaplin, Pauline Lafont, Stephane Audran, Andree Tainsy, Jean Topart.

results.title: Vivre Sa Vie = My Life to Live
results.brief_description:
Unable to pay her rent, Nana, a girl from the provinces, is gradually initiated into prostitution in Paris. Using interview techniques, direct sound, long takes, texts, quotation and statistics, Godard gives this probing and dazzling examination of prostitution (in 12 chapters) a documentary tone. The film is dedicated to B movies. Awards: Venice Film Festival (1962): Special jury prize.

Credits: Producer, Pierre Braunberger ; director, Jean-Luc Godard ; photography, Raoul Coutard ; music, Michel Legrand.
Cast: Anna Karina, Saddy Rebbot, Andre Labarthe, Peter Kassowitz.
